q: What is database monitoring?
o: The continuous observation of database performance and health metrics

q: What is a database metric?
o: A measurable value that indicates database performance or health

q: What is QPS (Queries Per Second)?
o: A metric measuring the number of queries executed per second

q: What is TPS (Transactions Per Second)?
o: A metric measuring the number of transactions completed per second

q: What is database latency?
o: The time delay between a request and its response
The time the database is late
The time to start the database

q: What is p50 latency?
o: The median latency - 50% of requests complete faster than this value

q: What is p95 latency?
o: The latency value below which 95% of requests complete

q: What is p99 latency?
o: The latency value below which 99% of requests complete

q: What is database throughput?
o: The amount of work a database can handle in a given time period

q: What is IOPS (Input/Output Operations Per Second)?
o: A metric measuring the number of read/write operations per second

q: What is database saturation?
o: The degree to which database resources are fully utilized
When the database is saturated with data

q: What is a database bottleneck?
o: A point in the system where performance is limited by a specific resource
A narrow part of the database

q: What is database capacity planning?
o: The process of determining future database resource requirements

q: What is vertical scaling (scale-up)?
o: Adding more resources (CPU, RAM, storage) to a single server

q: What is horizontal scaling (scale-out)?
o: Adding more servers to distribute the load

q: What is the main advantage of horizontal scaling over vertical scaling?
o: Better fault tolerance and theoretically unlimited scalability

q: What is the main disadvantage of horizontal scaling?
o: Increased complexity in managing distributed systems and data consistency

q: What is a database hotspot?
o: A portion of data that receives disproportionately high access compared to other data
A hot area in the database

q: What is data skew in distributed databases?
o: Uneven distribution of data across nodes

q: What is load skew in distributed databases?
o: Uneven distribution of query load across nodes

q: What is consistent hashing?
o: A hashing technique that minimizes data movement when nodes are added or removed

q: What is a virtual node in consistent hashing?
o: Multiple positions on the hash ring assigned to a single physical node to improve distribution

q: What is data locality in distributed systems?
o: The principle of keeping data close to where it is processed to reduce latency

q: What is a bloom filter?
o: A space-efficient probabilistic data structure used to test whether an element is in a set

q: What is the characteristic of a bloom filter?
o: It can have false positives but never false negatives
It can have false negatives but never false positives
It can have both false positives and negatives

q: What is a LSM tree (Log-Structured Merge-tree)?
o: A data structure optimized for write-heavy workloads by using sequential writes

q: What is compaction in LSM trees?
o: The process of merging and consolidating SSTables to reclaim space and improve read performance
The process of making data compact

q: What is an SSTable (Sorted String Table)?
o: An immutable, sorted file format used in LSM trees

q: What is a memtable?
o: An in-memory data structure where writes are initially stored before being flushed to disk

q: What is write amplification?
o: The phenomenon where the actual amount of data written to storage is greater than the logical amount

q: What is read amplification?
o: The phenomenon where reading data requires accessing multiple storage locations

q: What is space amplification?
o: The ratio of storage space used to actual data size due to overhead and redundancy

q: What is a B-tree?
o: A self-balancing tree data structure commonly used for database indexes

q: What is a B+ tree?
o: A variant of B-tree where all data is stored in leaf nodes and internal nodes only store keys

q: Why are B+ trees preferred over B-trees for databases?
o: Better for range queries and sequential access because all data is in leaf nodes

q: What is a hash index?
o: An index that uses a hash function to map keys to locations

q: What is the main limitation of hash indexes?
o: They do not support range queries efficiently

q: What is a bitmap index?
o: An index that uses bitmaps to represent the presence or absence of values

q: When are bitmap indexes most effective?
o: For columns with low cardinality (few distinct values)

q: What is a full-table scan?
o: A query execution method that reads every row in a table
A scan of the entire database

q: When might a full-table scan be more efficient than using an index?
o: When retrieving a large percentage of rows from a table

q: What is index selectivity?
o: The ratio of distinct values to total rows - higher selectivity means more efficient index
The ability to select an index

q: What is cardinality in the context of database columns?
o: The number of distinct values in a column
The number of rows in a table

q: What is high cardinality?
o: A column with many distinct values relative to the number of rows
A column with few distinct values

q: What is low cardinality?
o: A column with few distinct values relative to the number of rows
A column with many distinct values
